curriculum_alignment.subject: mathematics
curriculum_alignment.seeds_of_change: Construct and interpret diagrams for grouped continuous data, including histograms with unequal class intervals; interpret and compare distributions

verse_ality.driving_question: How can histograms show who gets more – and who gets less – in our world?

knowing_world.focus: Drawing and interpreting histograms using frequency density so bar area (not height) represents frequency

tools.name: Histogram & Frequency Density Explorer (SDG Contexts)
tools.purpose: Explore how frequency, class width and frequency density work together with SDG contexts

tools.name: Histogram Story Matcher (SDG Contexts)
tools.purpose: Practice reading histograms and matching to real SDG stories

tools.name: Interactive SDG Frequency Density Comparison
tools.purpose: Compare two histograms (two groups) on same axes

activities: Explore SDG contexts (water use, electricity, commute times)
Study tables of intervals, frequencies, frequency densities
Notice how wider bars with lower height can have same area as narrow high bars
Try 'My SDG Scenario' to design own variable and data

human_story.focus: Histograms show how a whole group's experiences are spread out, revealing inequality and resource pressure

sdg_contexts.title: Clean Water and Sanitation
sdg_contexts.description: Water use spread across households in two communities
sdg_contexts.justice_dimension: If one community's histogram shows most area at low use and another has long tail of high users, that tells story of inequality and pressure on resources

sdg_contexts.title: Affordable and Clean Energy
sdg_contexts.description: Electricity use varies between two regions
sdg_contexts.justice_dimension: Distribution patterns reveal energy equity issues

sdg_contexts.title: Sustainable Cities and Communities
sdg_contexts.description: Commute times before and after new bus or cycle route
sdg_contexts.justice_dimension: Changes in distribution show impact of infrastructure on accessibility

justice_prompts: Imagine these histograms being shown to city council or charity deciding where to focus support. What might they conclude from the shapes?
What might they miss if they only look at graphs and not the people?
activities: Compare histograms of two communities on same axes
Identify which group has more area in low ranges
Notice which stretches into very high values
Use bar information (interval, density, area) to support ideas

expressive_self.focus: Histogram as skyline of a city made from data
metaphors: Short squat bars = lots of people with similar experiences
Tall spikes = big differences or 'crowds' at certain values
Long tails = few people experiencing extreme values

activities.prompt: Sketch simple histogram by hand and label with words like 'most people here', 'few people here', 'extreme cases here'
Write mini-story starting with: 'If you walked along the base of this histogram, you would see...'

reflection_prompts: Which feels easier for you – looking at histogram and describing story, or starting with story and building histogram to match?

designed_world.focus: Engineers, planners and campaigners use histograms to design fairer systems
real_world_applications: Designing bus timetables based on commute time distributions
Planning water supply or storage based on household usage patterns
Setting sensible targets for screen time, sleep or exercise

steps: Pick variable (e.g. commute time, water litres, screen time)
Imagine change (e.g. more buses, conservation campaign)
Describe how you'd want histogram to change: shift left (shorter times/lower use), become more concentrated (more equal), lose extreme tails
Optionally build 'before and after' in Activity 3 custom mode

ethical_prompts: If you redesigned a system based on histograms, how would you check that changes really help people in the 'worst' part of distribution, not just improve the average?

emotional_awareness: Seeing data about sleep, commute, water or energy can bring up feelings: 'That's unfair', 'I'm one of unlucky ones', 'I'm using too much'
It's okay to notice these feelings. You are not a bar on a graph.

regulation_supports.trigger: When data brings up difficult feelings about inequality or self-judgment
instructions: Look away from screen and find 3 objects in room that are calm or comforting
Take slow in-breath for 4 counts and imagine drawing gentle curve
Exhale for 6 counts and imagine smoothing out tension in shoulders

wellbeing_prompts: How can you use what you learn from histograms to support your own wellbeing – for example, by noticing patterns in your sleep or screen time without judging yourself?

neurodivergent_considerations: Multiple entry points via 5 Ways of Knowing
Regulation pause embedded when data might trigger difficult feelings

pathways.name: One Histogram, Deep Dive
steps: Use Activity 1 to build histogram for one SDG data set
Write down grouped table with: class intervals, frequencies, frequency densities
Write paragraph (6-8 sentences) describing what histogram shows: where most values lie, any long tails or extremes, what this means in SDG context
products: Screenshot or copied table/values from histogram app
Grouped frequency table including frequency densities

pathways.name: Two Histograms Compared
steps: Use Activity 3 to compare two groups (Community A vs B, before vs after change)
Record key features of each histogram: ranges with most area, differences in spread and extremes
Write comparison paragraph explaining: which group has 'better' outcomes, which shows more variability, what questions this raises about fairness or access
products: Screenshot(s) or copied tables from histogram apps
Grouped frequency tables for both distributions

rubric_criteria.focus: Correctly explain histograms, class width, frequency density, and interpret shapes
Calculations (class width, frequency density) and descriptions of histogram are accurate
Use histogram to answer meaningful questions in SDG context, not just restate numbers
Reflect thoughtfully on what distribution suggests about fairness or inequality, in own words

dependencies: Canva embed: Histogram & Frequency Density Explorer
Canva embed: SDG Frequency Density Comparison
technical.accessibility_notes: All Canva tools include keyboard navigation; screen reader testing recommended

licensing.safeguarding_notes: SDG contexts may raise feelings about inequality; regulation pause provided to support learners processing these emotions
